Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Scalable RDF Query Processing Using a Cloud Infrastructure

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Resource Description Framework (RDF) has, in recent years, become an increasingly important data and knowledge representation formalism for a broad range of applications, including the World Wide Web. With rapidly growth in the size of RDF datasets, there is growing need for scalable and efficient technologies for storing, indexing, and querying RDF datasets that are trillions of triples in size. This project, led by Dr. Praveen Rao of University of Missouri-Kansas City, aims to address this need by developing: (1) A novel approach to storing, indexing, and querying of RDF data that treats graphs as first-class citizens to reduce the cost and number of joins required for graph pattern matching using RDF signatures, RDF signature indexes and line graphs; (2) A new approach for parallel SPARQL query processing on cloud platforms using data distribution schemes based on RDF signatures, location index for quickly finding RDF graphs of interest across computing nodes, and a gossip-driven query execution model and (3) A new approach for selectivity estimation of RDF graph patterns for query optimization based on new gossip algorithms for cardinality estimation of RDF graph patterns and a divide-andconquer method for effective load balancing and improved accuracy.


The broader impacts of this project include new courses covering topics in RDF data management and cloud computing, a scalable RDF reasoning tool over cancer data for oncologists, new cloud services for very large RDF data stores, increased opportunities for research-based advanced training of undergraduate and graduate students, including women. The results of this research, including publications, software, and data sets will be freely shared with the broader community. Additional information about the can be accessed through the project website at http://vortex.sce.umkc.edu/ric.html.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Resource Description Framework (RDF) has become the standard model for data representation and interchange on the Web [1]. RDF is a core standard of Semantic Web technologies and has gained a lot of attention for new use cases on the Web and in domain-specific applications. RDF has the ability to represent data in machine processable form and enables easy integration of diverse data sources. With the growing size of RDF datasets on the Web, it has become a major challenge to speed up the processing of queries expressed by users to access relevant information in these datasets. As a result, users can retrieve relevant information as quickly as possible. The goal of this project was to investigate new methods and techniques for fast processing of user queries over RDF and semistructured datasets.

Intellectual Merit:

This project led to new methods and techniques for large-scale data management and health informatics. The key outcomes are (a) a new approach for fast query processing over large RDF datasets in a centralized setting; (b) a new decentralized algorithm for computing aggregates over semistructured data stored in distributed environment (e.g., a cloud computing platform); (c) a new distributed framework for querying clinical data represented in HL7 Clinical Document Architecture standard; and (d) a smartphone application for tracking the vaccination coverage of children in rural communities.

Broader Impacts:

This project resulted in one Ph.D. dissertation, 4 M.S. theses, and 3 B.S. research projects at University of Missouri-Kansas City (UMKC). A total of 10 students were mentored; two of the students were female. The research findings of this project were disseminated in the form of 12 peer-reviewed publications (i.e., 6 journal, 4 conference, and 2 workshop publications) and a tutorial. At UMKC, a new graduate course on big data management was developed. Concepts on RDF indexing and query processing and cloud computing was integrated into an existing graduate course. In collaboration with IBM, a hackathon was organized for students at UMKC to build creative data-driven applications using IBM’s cloud computing platform.

For more details about the project (e.g., publications, software packages), visit http://sites.google.com/site/umkcric.

References

[1] http://www.w3.org/RDF/


Last Modified: 04/13/2016
Modified by: Praveen R Rao
